"Where?"
"Can't you see'um?" he whispered. "All the Terabithians standing on tiptoe to see you."
"Me?"

What were your favorite books as a child? 

Two of my favorite books during my childhood were: 

üìöHoles by Louis Sachar &

üìöBridge to Terabithia by Katherine Paterson

‚ÄúIt was up to him to pay back to the world in beauty and caring what Leslie had loaned him in vision and strength.‚Äù

Bridge to Terabithia is so beautiful, wonderful, and full of heart, but I‚Äôm not sure I can ever read it again. One of those books that breaks your heart and you can‚Äôt forget it because it is so good. I read it the same time the movie came out and remember seeing it almost immediately after and the movie being just as wonderful and just as heart wrenching. It teaches so much about love, loss, and grief, so it‚Äôs a hard read, but a beautiful and important one.

Good morning readers! 
I'm sure most of you know today's book: Bridge to Terabithia by Katherine Paterson... but you probably know it as that movie that made you cry till you ran out of tears.
Well, just like the movie, the book is absolutely brilliant. 
Two lonely kids come together to create an imaginary world where they can play and be themselves. It's a heart wrenching tale of friendship, imagination, childhood, and tragedy. 
But I'm warning you now, though this book is beautiful it'll leave you feeling like you've been punched in the gut.

‚ÄúYou never know ahead of time what something's really going to be like.‚Äù - Bridge to Terabithia

Number 17 this year... It's difficult for me to accurately or adequately express how much Katherine Paterson's BRIDGE TO TERABITHIA means to me.  Seventeen years ago, my fellow soldiers and I faced a very difficult time in the war in Afghanistan. For an idea of what that was like read Jawad Arash's and my novel ENDURING FREEDOM, but, in short, I was nearly broken, with little hope.  Then this book came in the mail. And reading it was incredible.  It offered hope, something besides guns and filth and fear.  It taught me that there is still hope, even in the most difficult times.  And it taught me that beauty and art and literature are not frivilous extras, but are essential to the human spirit and to survival.  That's why I'm so grateful that my dear friend Katherine Paterson allowed my ENDURING FREEDOM characters to read and quote from this book.  I read or listen to this book every year now, and I try to do so on the hottest July day, just to experience this wonderful novel closer to the way I did back there in Afghanistan.  When I'm doing a book show and kids ask me, "What's your favorite book?" Oh yeah, right here.  BRIDGE TO TERABITHIA.  If you have not read it yet, regardless of your age, I beg you to do so.  You owe it to yourself.

Review timeüíê
Haii kembali lagi... Kali ini aku mau review salah satu buku judulnya Bridge to Terabithia, karya Katherine Paterson yang benar-benar membekas dihati dan belum bisa move on setelah membacanya.. pokoknya kalian HARUS BANGET deh baca bukunya! (BACA REVIEW INI SAMPAI HABIS!! PARAGRAF 4 HARUS BANGET!)ü§Ø

Jadi buku ini sebenarnya adalah buku novel anak, dari awal direkomendasikan udah dibilangin tuh kalau ini buku  novel anak, sangat ringan, tapi katanya ceritanya bagus dan manis banget, bahkan sampai difilm kan! ( Dengan judul yang sama; Bridge to Terabithia) 
(Lihat Clio dari filmnya dipostingan aku selanjutnya ya.. coming soon!)
Ceritanya memang sederhana, tidak bertele-tele, bahkan bisa dibilang seolah 'less conflict'. Tapiii bener apa yang Marie Rutkoski bilang, cerita ini bener-bener bisa mengharu biru hati para pembacanya dengan kisah persahabatan sederhana didalamnya.

 Dan uniknya, Katherine berhasil membawakan suasana persahabatan mereka bener-bener seperti suasana di real life, dimana 
üìåSetelah kita merasakan kebahagiaan tak berarti itu selamanya, kebahagiaan lahir dari jatuh sedih dan begitu pula sebaliknya, kesedihan pula bisa jadi lahir dari kebahagiaan, bukankah begitu? Dan konsep ini benar-benar dipaparkan secara gamblang oleh sang penulis dalam buku "anak" ini.ü•∫ 
UPS, maaf nggak berani spoiler lebih lanjut, ya. Takut diserbu para haters spoilerüòÜ
Tapi kalau mau aq spoiler di postingan selanjutnya, comment ya guys!

Apalagi setelah kawan semua menonton film-nya, feel nya makin kerasa deh! üòç
Tapi tetap aku saranin baca bukunya dulu baru nonton filmnya, yah. Baru kalian bisa dapet feel yang aku maksudkan. Walaupun baca bukunya aja juga udah berhasil mengharu biru hatikuuuuüòñ, ditambah filmnya jadi makin makin deeehhh
 Kiranya segitu dulu, apabila mau tanya jawab boleh banget niii di kolom komentar yaa... Byeeeee

so we have to talk about itü§∑üèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è..
Leslie‚Äôs death. So sad.. The scene you see first is the last time we see Leslie. Jess goes on a  field trip with Ms. Edmunds and the next scene is Jess finding out that Leslie is dead. The trauma this scene caused me as a kidü§¶üèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è.

Now me personally i loved Leslie from the second they introduced her to the book/movie. I loved how she was different, smart, always happy and mostly how she always supported Jesse. I feel like everyone needs a Leslie Burke in their lifeüòâ!!
The fact that her family stands out by being smarter than almost everyone else in the neighborhood. This influences Leslie as well and helps her develop her own uniqueness and distinct flair.
Leslie‚Äôs family is affluent and well educated, in stark contrast with the rest of the residents in the area, and has an entirely different slant on life than any of the neighbors.
She is highly intelligent and imaginative, she is founder of Terabithia. It was her idea to build a fantasyland named Terabithia across the creek.
Lets introduce Leslie Burke! She is Jesse‚Äôs new next-door neighbor and becomes his best friend. ( i‚Äôm breaking it down just like i did with Jesse)

He becomes more quiet, and he tries to push Leslie away telling her to ‚Äúget her head out of the clouds‚Äù which is the same this his dad tells him to do. I really had disliked him for saying that, and really letting his dad get to him like that.

* proof * 
Now Jesse goes out of his way to take the pest out of the garden house and free him into the wild. Which was the right the to do and he knows that, but when he gets back to the garden house. To put the cage back he is caught by his dad and his dad discredits him about his art, and tells him he did the wrong thing and he should ‚Äúget his head out of the clouds‚Äù . Which basically means focus and toughen up and that causes Jesse to act like this....

Now that‚Äôs how the book describes Jesse and although he is talented and smart. I think his character is weak especially shown in the movie, i‚Äôll provide evidence after this. But like i was saying I feel he‚Äôs weak because i feel he cares about what others think especially at the beginning i do come around on him later on in the story though.
Jesse is very talented, as well as smart, caring, and down to earth. A thoroughly likable character, and every other person would be drawn to his character.
Jesse is a budding artist whose talent receives little praise from everyone except Leslie(i‚Äôll introduce her next), and Miss Edmunds.

This is Jesse Aaron he‚Äôs one of the main characters. So i‚Äôm going to tell y‚Äôall some of his character traits.
